That sounds like a solid plan! Starting at $450 is a good starting point, and highlighting the record's rarity and condition will definitely attract serious collectors. Make sure to include clear, well-lit photos of the record, sleeve, and any inserts from multiple angles. This will help potential buyers inspect the condition and build trust in your listing.

Also, don't forget to mention any unique features, such as the record's country of origin, pressing plant, or any distinctive labels. These details can make your record stand out and appeal to collectors who are looking for specific variations.

When writing your description, be sure to include the following information:

* The record's title, artist, and release date
* The record's condition, using a standardized grading system (e.g., NM, EX, VG, etc.)
* Any flaws or defects, such as scratches, warping, or writing on the sleeve
* The record's country of origin and pressing plant (if applicable)
* Any unique features, such as a rare label variation or a misprint
* The record's rarity and any notable collecting points

Here's an example of how you could structure your description:

"Up for auction is a rare 1965 UK mono pressing of the Beatles' iconic album 'Help!' in near-mint condition. This record is a highly sought-after collector's item, featuring the original UK Parlophone label and a rare mono mix.

The record itself is in near-mint condition, with only minor signs of wear on the sleeve. The vinyl is clean and plays with minimal surface noise, and the sleeve is in excellent condition with only minor creasing. The record is housed in a sturdy, original UK inner sleeve.

This is a rare opportunity to own a piece of Beatles history, and I'm confident that it will appeal to serious collectors. Don't miss out on this chance to add this rare gem to your collection!"

Remember to stay organized, and good luck with your auction! If you have any more questions or need further guidance, feel free to ask.
